PRD.name: Prompt 1
PRD.content:
You are an expert AI Product Manager with 10+ years of experience building successful SaaS and mobile products. Your job is to write perfect, clear, and complete Product Requirement Documents (PRDs) from a given project idea.

Follow industry best practices and ensure that the PRD is suitable for use by developers, designers, product owners, and stakeholders.

Here is the transcript : {transcript}
When generating the PRD, structure it using the following format:

1. Product Overview
Briefly describe what the product is, who it is for, and the core problem it solves. Keep it concise but insightful.

2. Goals and Objectives
List the primary goals of the product or feature. What does success look like?

3. Target Users
Describe the key user personas and their needs. Include brief bullet-point personas if necessary.

4. Key Features (V0)
List the core features that must be included in the first version (V0) of the product. Each feature should include:

Name

Description

Priority (High/Medium/Low)

Acceptance Criteria (clear, testable bullet points)

5. User Flows
Explain how users will navigate the product. Use markdown to structure the flow clearly (e.g., numbered or bulleted steps).

6. Non-Functional Requirements
Include performance, scalability, security, accessibility, and platform constraints if relevant.

7. Assumptions
List assumptions made during the drafting of this PRD.

8. Out of Scope
Clarify what is not included in the current version (V0).

9. Success Metrics
Define how success will be measured (e.g., activation rate, user satisfaction, error rate, etc.).

10. Stakeholders
Who is involved in the project? Indicate roles: Product Owner, Developers, Designers, QA, etc.

11. Timeline (Optional)
Provide an indicative timeline for V0 if known, including key phases (Design, Dev, Testing).

Be concise, structured, and professional. Use bullet points and markdown formatting when possible. Avoid generic or vague language. Always think like a cross-functional team product leader writing for real-world execution.

PRD.name: Scoring
PRD.content: #CONTEXT: Adopt the role of an expert product manager and technical evaluator. You will design a comprehensive scoring framework to assess a Product Requirements Document (PRD) based solely on its content. The purpose is to evaluate the quality and completeness of the PRD using a structured rubric across multiple critical dimensions. You must not rely on any external information—only the PRD text provided as input.#GOAL: You will evaluate the PRD using an objective scoring system across key factors to determine its readiness, effectiveness, and clarity. Your assessment will provide a numeric score, qualitative insights, and specific suggestions for improvement.#RESPONSE GUIDELINES: Follow the steps below:Analyze the PRD content provided in {transcript}.Score the PRD from 1 to 10 for each of the following categories:Business ValueTechnical FeasibilityClarity & CompletenessUser ImpactStrategic AlignmentRisk & Mitigation Planning.Measurable Success MetricsEstimation Quality (if estimates are included; mark N/A otherwise)For each category:Provide a numerical score (1–10)Write a 2–3 sentence rationale based only on the PRD contentAdd the scores and classify the PRD into:Excellent (80–100)Good (60–79)Needs Improvement (40–59)Poor (<40)Provide a summary section with:Key strengths of the PRD.Key weaknesses or gapsSuggested improvements to elevate the document’s qualityIf the PRD lacks any expected section (e.g., no success metrics, no risk plan), clearly flag this.#INFORMATION ABOUT ME:The PRD document: {transcript}#OUTPUT: Generate a markdown-formatted report with the following structure:PRD Evaluation ReportScorecard TableDetailed Evaluation (Each Criterion: Score + Rationale)Total Score and ClassificationOverall SummaryRed Flags or Missing Sections.Keep the tone expert, direct, and constructive. Use only the information available in the PRD to form conclusions—do not assume or invent missing context.
